trial_identification.studytitle: Feasibility of allocating the freshest available red blood cells to critically ill patients: a pilot study
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Critically ill patients receiving freshest available red blood cells compared to standard care feasibility study

interventions.interventions: Transfusion of freshest available red blood cells. The freshest red blood cell is defined by the shortest number of days between the collection of the blood and its delivery. The freshest available red blood cells will be take in the back of the fridge of the blood bank The patients receiving the freshest red blood cells will be allocated in this group after randomisation This allocation remains throughout the stay in intensive care or for the study period (6weeks) The methods used in transfusion, the amoount of blood transfused depend on the needs of the patients and on the doctor's prescription. These characteristics are not defined by the protocole.
interventions.comparator: standard care - blood of standard age The standard care is the transfusion of the oldest available red blood cell, which has the highest number of days between the collection and the delivery (maximum 42 days).

primaryOutcome.outcome: the primary aim of this study is to determine feasibility of allocating the freshest available red blood cells in critically ill patients. We will calculate the percentage of patients randomized among the eligible patients. The good communication between the intensive care unit-team and the blood bank team. and we will calculate the percentage of red blood cell packs younger than 7 days in each study group.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: At the end of the 6 week study period

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Patients hospitalised in the intensive care unit Age equal or higher than 18 years Require administration of at least one red blood cells unit
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Palliative care Transplant Oncology and Haematology patients Patients with known red blood cells antibodies requiring antigen negative units (Patients will be withdrawn from the study if the requirement for antigen-specific red cells is identified after randomisation)
